[All disciples are busy eating Jesus's body and blood]

Jesus: I think there is a betrayer in one of you guys.
Peter: Wow, hold on, there is a BETRAYER here?
Jesus: Yes, and I'll find him before we go to Gethsemane.
Peter: Don't try that alone, Master! We will help you!
Bartholomew: Yeah! We must protect our master!
Andrew: That makes sense. Let us do it together!
Jesus: Good, now my first question: How much money did the betrayer gained for betraying me? Guess a number. Andrew, you go first.
Andrew: Um... *counts the fingers* ...I guess $10?
Bartholomew: But wait, how can he gain any money from this act?
Matthew: Because Judas betrayed his master last year when he worked as tax collector...
Judas: Umm... (stops eating)
John: Oh yeah! I remember that story. You got caught by the Pharisees
James (greater): And you had to return all those money back.
Philip: So what's your answer again, Andrew?
Andrew: Uh... 1 dollar!
Thomas: This is silly! Unless we know who betrays, how can we even estimate the price?
Jesus: No matter, just give an answer.
Peter: Okay, okay! He didn't make any money from this betrayal because he's stupid enough not to have thought about getting money!
Simon the Canaanite: Yeah!
Thaddaeus: Right! Besides, if he made any money from betraying Jesus, we would never follow him again!
[All disciples shout]
Jesus: Alright calm down! Next question: If one of you is a betrayer, which disciple are most likely to be a liar?
Peter: Definitely it is John!
John: Ha ha ha! Why am I gonna lie? Master knows I'm honest.
Bartholomew: Wait, then why do you think Peter said that?
Andrew: Because some people always tell lies and others don't always speak truthfully
Philip: Like Thomas. We know Thomas doesn't believe anything without direct experience.
Thomas: Hey! That was unfair. I only ask for proof before believing something.
Judas: *sigh* Actually everyone here except me tells lies sometimes, but their frequency differs greatly.
Jesus: Silence Judas! Alright next question: How many of you will deny Jesus when questioned by the guards at Gethsemane tonight?
John: Me? Never!
James (greater): Same with me.
Matthew: Um... maybe...
Thaddaeus: Yes, we won't deny our master. Even though we're zealots.
Peter: Oh yeah! Of course not, Master! You know my loyalty as well as my bravery!
Jesus: What about Andrew?
Andrew: Uh... depends on what they say...
Simon the Canaanite: Ha ha! I'll definitely deny!
Judas: *whispers to Simon* Let's both deny together.
Simon the Canaanite: Okay, sure thing!
Bartholomew: Not fair! I didn't even have a chance to answer yet.
Philip: Yeah, let him try first.
Jesus: Alright Bartholomew, how many of you will deny me tonight?
Bartholomew: Umm... Two.
James (lesser): Wait, which two?
Bartholomew: No idea.
Judas: *whispering to James lesser* Don't worry it is not us.
James (lesser): Then who are those two guys?
[All disciples start fighting and shouting]
Jesus: Stop. Seems like the betrayer is smart. Who is the smartest among you, in other words, do you think you're smart?
Andrew: Haha, Peter always thinks he's so clever but actually he just pretend to be dumb
Peter: Hey!
Philip: Actually I'm pretty smart too. In fact I was one of the most successful fisherman before joining Jesus' group.
Thomas: And don't forget Matthew; He used to collect taxes for the Romans, although Judas may disagree with that statement
Matthew: That's true, however, now I feel very ashamed of my past actions
Judas: Hey! You can say whatever you want about others' past mistakes but leave mine alone.
Bartholomew: We all make mistakes after all.
Jesus: Silence everyone. Next question: If there is a fight here at dinner time, who would defend me the best?
John: Of course, Master! It has to be me or Peter or both of us together!
Thaddaeus: Ha ha! John might protect you because he thinks he loves you more than anyone else
Simon the Canaanite: Yeah maybe except when we argue over our master's policy.
Peter: *indignant* Shut up Simon!
Jesus: Enough! Alright last question: Which disciple ate less food tonight compared to normal?
Philip: Ahah... Thaddaeus always eat less food because he says fasting makes him closer to God.
Judas: Don't forget Thomas. Although his diet seems not affected by what he believes.
Thomas: Hey that's true! I am quite hungry though...
Thaddaeus: Oh yeah and another thing, if we fast then why do I have such a big belly? (points)
Andrew: Uh..
Matthew: Maybe it is Thaddeus' digestive system which doesn't agree with your theory about fasting making people thinner
[All disciples shout in laughter]
Jesus: Alright I know who betrayed me now. When I get home, I eat one of the apples and then throw another one out of the window just to see how far I can throw it. I then give 2 of them to my dog, who loves eating apples. Afterwards, I go to the bedroom and put one on my bed because I always get hungry in the middle of the night, and then I put 2 of them in the fridge.

A few hours later, my neighbor comes and returns the apple I gave him and leaves. I put that apple back in the bag. Later that day, I go to the Apple store and buy 4 Apple iPhones, put them in the bag, and give one of the apples inside the bag to the seller as a tip. I return home and put 2 of those Apple phones into the fridge.

My neighbor comes again and asks, "If you have any apples in your fridge, can I have one?" I say yes and give him one of the Apple phones, and - to my surprise - he starts eating it, which leads me to call emergency services to take him to the hospital.

The surrounding Arab nationsâ€”Egypt, Transjordan, Syria, Iraq, Lebanon, and Saudi Arabiaâ€”rejected the UN partition plan and launched a military intervention. The war resulted in significant territorial changes, the displacement of a large number of Palestinian Arabs, and set the stage for ongoing conflict in the Middle East.

### Questions
1. **Origins and Background of the War**
    - What international and regional factors triggered the war following Israel's declaration of independence in 1948?
    - Considering the historical context of the Palestinian issue, how would you analyze the causes of this war?

2. **Course and Outcomes of the War**
    - Describe the strategies and tactics employed by the involved nations during the war, and evaluate their successes and failures.
    - Explain the political and social changes that the Middle East experienced as a result of this war.

3. **Long-term and Contemporary Impacts**
    - Discuss the impact of the First Arab-Israeli War on modern Middle Eastern affairs, providing specific examples.
    - How do you think this war has influenced the current relationship between Israel and Palestine?

4. **Hypothetical Scenarios**
    - If the Arab nations had chosen to engage in peaceful negotiations instead of military action following Israel's declaration in 1948, what scenarios might have unfolded?
    - In the absence of this war, how do you predict the political map and international relations of the Middle East would have evolved?

5. **Lessons and Future Prospects**
    - What lessons should be learned from the First Arab-Israeli War? How can these lessons be applied to contemporary international politics?
    - What policies or approaches do you believe would be effective in achieving lasting peace and stability in the Middle East in the future?

Description: The prompts focus on various methods and challenges in creating data visualizations using libraries like Matplotlib, Seaborn, Plotly, and others, addressing issues such as dynamic labeling, dual-axis plotting, clustering visualization, and layout adjustments.
Example Prompt:
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from calendar import month_name

# Assuming df setup is done as before
# ...

# Function to get the first week of each month in the data range
def get_first_weeks_of_months(df):
    # Find unique months in the dataset
    unique_months = df['date'].dt.to_period('M').unique()
    first_weeks = []
    
    for month in unique_months:
        first_day_of_month = month.to_timestamp()
        week_number = df[df['date'] >= first_day_of_month]['week'].min()
        if week_number not in first_weeks:  # Avoid duplicates
            first_weeks.append(week_number)
    
    return sorted(first_weeks)

# Get the first weeks of months
first_weeks = get_first_weeks_of_months(df)

# Create the heatmap as before
# ...

# Add month labels dynamically
for week in first_weeks:
    if week in data.index:  # Ensure the week is within our plotted data
        month = df[df['week'] == week]['date'].dt.month_name().iloc[0]
        # Positioning the text slightly above the heatmap row
        plt.text(-0.5, list(data.index).index(week) + 0.5, month, 
                 fontsize=12, fontweight='bold', ha='right', va='center')

# Continue with the rest of your plotting code
# ...

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

--

Description: The document discusses various applications and techniques for effectively utilizing Large Language Models (LLMs), including writing code, generating high-quality MCQs, summarizing complex documents, and creating innovative programs, while also touching on the limitations and future potential of LLMs.
Example Prompt:
Isn't an LLM would be best suited to write rust?
Think of it like that. Rust is just a language and LLMs lack of profeciency with it is just due to training data.
But what does rust offer?
1. It either compiler or it does not.
2. Verbose errors which points both an an LLM an human.
But most importantly:
3. Ability to overengineer.

You might ask: well how's that ever a good thing?
Consider this.
An LLM has a plan of what the app should do. Breaks it down into rough conceptual modules.
Then breaks it down into trais and files or maybe even microservices.

Then it doesn't have to think, like a junior doesn't have to think about their jira task - just do without thinking about it too hard! Essentially, my argument, when simplified, is an ECS one: "you can't plan everything ahead. I can't but he can.". It appears my clarification was a little off mark.
Consider this, instead.
So you're writing ECS code but now there's a need for an unexpected change.
With an LLM, there's no problem at all.
Just reevaluate the plan, update the ECS design plan and regenerate the affected modules to align with the new plan.
As opposited to human iterations where it would take the whole day and would require tediously rewriting it all. For LLM? If the codebase is big, fine, let's say 15 minutes. Do you now see the logic?
Where other languages allow to "move fast break things", rust only allows to move either fast or slow.
But moving fast isn't always easy either - but that's where LLM can move fast, instead.|||I am using some LLM to make some MCQ

Description: The prompts focus on rewriting and summarizing academic content, improving writing style, and discussing strategies for academic success, such as active reading, note-taking, and time management, as well as exploring educational topics like degree options and the impact of distance learning.
Example Prompt:
rewrite this paragraph like i'm a college student: 

Three key strategies for academic success are active reading, effective note-taking, and strategic time management. Active reading involves engaging critically with texts by highlighting key points, jotting down questions, and summarizing main ideas in the margins. This approach helps with comprehension and retention of material. The SQ3R method (Survey, Question, Read, Recite, Review) is a particularly effective active reading strategy. It involves surveying the text before reading to get an overview, formulating questions to guide your reading, actively reading while seeking answers to those questions, reciting key points after reading each section, and reviewing the material afterwards. 

Effective note-taking means capturing essential information during lectures or while studying, using techniques like the Cornell method to organize main ideas, supporting details, and summary points. The Cornell method involves dividing your notepaper into sections for notes, cues/questions, and a summary. This aids in review and synthesizing information later. It's important to review and rewrite notes soon after class to reinforce learning. Creating mind maps can also be an effective visual note-taking technique, allowing you to graphically represent connections between ideas.

Strategic time management involves prioritizing tasks, breaking larger assignments into manageable chunks, and using tools like calendars and to-do lists to stay on top of deadlines. It's crucial to schedule specific blocks of time for reading and studying, preferably when you're most alert. Avoid multitasking, as it reduces focus and efficiency. Taking regular short breaks can help maintain concentration and avoid fatigue.

When reading textbooks, it's important to understand their structure and utilize features like chapter previews, learning objectives, introductions, summaries, and review questions. These elements can guide your reading and help you focus on key concepts. For scientific texts, pay attention to hypotheses and experimental design. For social science texts, consider the author's perspective and potential biases.

Building vocabulary is another crucial aspect of academic success. Actively look for new words in your reading, infer their meaning from context, look them up, and make a conscious effort to use them in your own writing and speech. This not only improves your comprehension but also enhances your ability to express complex ideas.

I've used active reading techniques in my literature courses, which has improved my ability to analyze texts. For example, I now preview chapters before reading, formulate questions based on headings, and actively seek answers as I read. For note-taking, I've started using the Cornell method this semester and found it super helpful for exam prep. I create cues and questions in the left column during lectures, which makes reviewing much more efficient. As for time management, I'm still working on it, but I've started using a digital planner to schedule specific study blocks and break down larger assignments into smaller tasks with deadlines. I've also made a habit of reviewing new vocabulary weekly. These strategies have definitely boosted my academic performance and reduced stress by helping me stay on top of my coursework and retain information more effectively.

In this course, I've gained a comprehensive understanding of the wide array of degree options available in higher education. This knowledge is crucial for several reasons and has significant implications for my academic and career planning.

Firstly, I learned that college degrees range from associate's to doctoral levels, each with distinct credit requirements and career focuses. For instance, associate's degrees typically require about 60 credits and can be completed in two years, while bachelor's degrees usually necessitate 120 credits over four years. This information is vital because it allows me to align my educational pursuits with my career goals and personal circumstances. For example, if I'm interested in a technical field requiring hands-on skills, an Associate of Applied Science (AAS) might be the most suitable option. Conversely, if I'm aiming for a profession that demands more advanced knowledge, I would need to consider a bachelor's degree or beyond.

Moreover, I've discovered that some careers require specific degree levels. The course provided a table showing examples of jobs by minimum degree qualification, which is incredibly helpful for career planning. For instance, I now know that becoming a radiology technician typically requires an associate's degree, while pursuing a career as a lawyer or college professor necessitates a graduate degree. This knowledge helps me set realistic expectations and plan my educational journey accordingly.

Additionally, I've learned about the concept of credit hours and how they relate to degree completion. Understanding that courses are typically assigned 1-6 credits based on the time spent interacting with course material is crucial for planning my academic workload each semester. This knowledge also helps me appreciate the depth and breadth of study required for different degree levels.

Furthermore, the course introduced me to various tools and resources for exploring degree options and career paths. For instance, it mentioned free online self-assessments like MyPlan, MAPP Test, and the Career Cluster Interest Survey. These tools can help me identify my interests and strengths, allowing me to make more informed decisions about my academic and career path.

Lastly, I've gained insight into the different types of associate's and bachelor's degrees. For example, I now understand the difference between an Associate of Applied Arts (AAA) or Science (AAS) focused on technical careers, and an Associate of Arts (AA) or Science (AS) designed for transfer to a bachelor's program. Similarly, I've learned about the distinctions between a Bachelor of Arts (BA), Bachelor of Science (BS), Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN), and Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA).

This comprehensive understanding of degree options is invaluable as I navigate my educational journey. It allows me to make informed decisions about my academic path, considering factors such as time commitment, career goals, and personal circumstances. Firstly, online teachers need to provide technical support, ensuring that students have the necessary skills and tools to navigate the online learning environment. This support enables students to become independent users of technology, which is essential for their autonomy (Ludwig & Tassinari, 2023). Secondly, teachers may take on the role of â€œinstructional designerâ€ (Hagel & Shaw, 2006:285), offering pedagogical support by designing engaging and interactive learning experiences that cater to diverse learning styles and preferences. They guide students in setting goals, planning their learning process, and breaking down complex tasks into manageable steps. This pedagogical support helps students develop self-regulation skills and take ownership of their learning (Ludwig & Tassinari, 2023). Moreover, teachers play a crucial role in providing motivational and emotional support to students. They create a supportive and inclusive learning environment, offer encouragement, and address any challenges or concerns that students may face. This support boosts studentsâ€™ motivation, confidence, and resilience, leading to increased autonomy (Ludwig & Tassinari, 2023). Finally, teachers manage communication support effectively, keeping channels open for interaction and collaboration. This includes finding a balance between asynchronous and synchronous interaction (Ribbe & Bezanilla, 2013). While experienced learners tend to prefer asynchronous communication such as emails, discussion boards, and social media platforms as it allows them to interact with others at their own pace, inexperienced students may benefit from more direct and immediate communication like real-time discussions, where they can receive instant feedback and support. This ongoing communication fosters a sense of connection and belonging, which is vital for student engagement and autonomy (Ribbe & Bezanilla, 2013; Ludwig & Tassinari, 2023). In addition, in distance learning, students may face conflicts between their studies and other responsibilities in their home, social, and work environments (Lee & Choi, 2011). By facilitating connections and interactions among students, online teachers create a supportive community where capable peers can offer guidance and support to those who may need additional assistance.
To fulfil their roles, teachers require appropriate strategies to foster LA. These strategies, listed in Table 2.1, are adapted from the Recommendations for Online Course Development for Adult Learners outlined by Cercone (2008). The application of these strategies is relevant to this study as it focuses on investigating adult learners, aligning with the participants involved in the current research. Furthermore, these strategies aim to support learners in becoming self-directed and independent in online learning contexts, which is suitable for the context of the current study.

Title: A systematic review of eye tracking research on instructor presence in educational videos

The replacement of face-to-face teaching with digital instructional materials is prevalent nowadays. This is often accompanied by a reduction in social interactions between learners and also between students and instructors (Baber 2022). It is posited that social cues from another human beings during learning are important as it can activate social schemata in our long-term memory, which in turn positively influence our cognitive processes, motivation, and also emotion (CASTLE, Schneider et al. 2021). Since educational videos are very often utilized in digital learning, it is pragmatic to induce social processes by including a human instructor in educational videos (Beege et al., 2023). Nevertheless, many studies investigated the effects of instructor presence on learning performance and obtained mixed results. In order to find out why the findings remain inconclusive, it is of utmost importance to gain insights into how people unconsciously process information while watching educational videos. Technology which can collect objective data during the learning process such as eye tracking is widely used in this field of research.  
We reviewed 34 eye-tracking studies on instructor presence in order to answer several questions: (1) How does an instructor in educational videos can affect learning outcomes? (2) How are the eye-tracking data in the studies interpreted? (3) How does an instructor influence learnersâ€™ gaze behavior? (4) What is the relationship between learnersâ€™ gaze behavior and learning outcomes? And lastly, (5) what are the instructional design guidelines can be derived from the reviewed studies?
The results show that (1) instructor presence fosters learning, but only to some extent. (2) 97% of the studies interpreted the data by linking the eye movements and overt attention. (3) An instructor is an attention magnet; but when he or she uses techniques (e.g., pointing gestures) to effectively direct attention to relevant learning content shown on the screen, learners will focus more on the learning content. (4) The general findings concerning the association between eye-tracking data and learning performance are mixed; this is because there are so many factors that could affect the results. For example, although most of the eye-tracking data indicated that focusing more on a visible instructor can lead to better learning outcomes, this is not true when the instructor shows inappropriate social cues e.g. incongruent facial expressions and body movements. Besides, there are also findings which indicated that looking at the relevant content faster and longer improves performance. (5) Lastly, 71% of the reviewed studies suggested adding a visible instructor into a video lesson, and authors suggested instructors using attentional cues (e.g. pointing gestures and guided gaze) and social cues (e.g. positive emotion and direct eye gaze) during a lesson.

   14. - Use a narrative, thought-provoking style.
   15. - Connect the topic with current trends, real-life examples, or recent studies.
   16. - Do not include a title, introductory phrases, or images. Write the content directly."

5. **Chapter 16: General Knowledge Quizzes as Part of Games and Activities: A Focus on Community Engagement**

6. **Introduction**
   Quizzes are not only a fun and engaging way to test knowledge and comprehension; they can also serve as powerful tools for promoting social responsibility, fostering civic engagement, and building stronger communities. In this chapter, we will explore the concept of using general knowledge quizzes as games and activities to promote community engagement, drawing inspiration from the commendable efforts of corporations such as Chubb Insurance in their Annual Regional Day of Service. We will delve into the theoretical foundations, practical applications, and potential impacts of such initiatives, emphasizing the transformative power of collective action and learning.

7. **Theoretical Foundations**
   24. **A. Social Responsibility and Civic Engagement**
   The idea of using general knowledge quizzes as games and activities for community engagement is rooted in the concepts of social responsibility and civic engagement. Social responsibility refers to an individual's or organization's obligation to contribute positively to society and the environment, while civic engagement encompasses the actions individuals take to identify and address issues affecting their communities (Brudney, 2018). By creating quizzes focused on local issues, history, culture, and social challenges, participants can enhance their understanding of these topics and feel empowered to make a difference.

8. **B. Collective Action and Learning**
   Collective action and learning theory posits that when individuals come together to learn and work towards common goals, they create synergistic effects that lead to greater outcomes than if they acted alone (Wenger, 1998). This approach highlights the importance of collaboration and shared experiences in driving meaningful change. By incorporating general knowledge quizzes into games and activities designed to engage the community, organizers can facilitate connections between participants, encourage dialogue, and foster a sense of shared purpose.

9. **Practical Applications**
   34. **A. Collaboration with Not-For-Profit Organizations and Business Partners**
   To ensure the success and sustainability of general knowledge quiz initiatives, it is essential to establish partnerships with not-for-profit organizations and businesses operating within the target community. These alliances can provide valuable insights into pressing social issues, help connect organizations with relevant stakeholders, and offer resources necessary for planning and executing events. For instance, Chubb Insurance has demonstrated the value of cross-sectoral collaboration by working closely with non-profits and business partners to craft initiatives aimed at increasing educational opportunities for underprivileged children (Chubb, 2019).

10. **B. Selecting Relevant Topics**
    Selecting appropriate themes and questions for general knowledge quizzes is crucial for capturing participants' interest and ensuring maximum impact. Ideally, topics should be tied to the specific needs and interests of the target community, covering areas such as local history, environmental concerns, health disparities, or economic development. Additionally, incorporating diverse perspectives and voices into question creation can help promote inclusivity and respect for diversity (Flanagan & Faison, 2001).

11. **C. Implementation Strategies**
    There are various strategies for implementing general knowledge quizzes as games and activities for community engagement. Some options include hosting live trivia nights at local venues, organizing virtual quizzes through online platforms, or integrating quizzes into existing community events. Regardless of the chosen format, it is important to consider factors such as accessibility, convenience, and incentives for participation to maximize reach and effectiveness (Klandermans et al., 2004).

12. **Potential Impacts**
    48. **A. Increased Public Awareness and Understanding**
    One significant outcome of utilizing general knowledge quizzes as games and activities for community engagement is increased public awareness and understanding of critical issues facing the community. Through active participation, individuals may gain new insights, develop empathy, and feel motivated to take action (Bandura, 2001). Moreover, well-designed quizzes can spark curiosity and inspire further investigation beyond the scope of the activity itself.

Description: The prompts focus on understanding and managing the health, behavior, and well-being of pets, particularly cats and dogs.
Example Prompt:
What Is High Blood Sugar in Cats?
Your catâ€™s body runs on glucose, just like the human body. The glucose level in the blood is tightly controlled by feedback mechanisms. This is called glucose homeostasis.

When glucose is absorbed from the gut after eating, an organ called the pancreas recognizes the higher glucose levels and produces insulin. This hormone moves extra glucose into cells where it can be used or stored, keeping the glucose in the blood at safe levels. When blood glucose gets low, the pancreas releases a different hormone called glucagon that tells the liver to release glucose again. This raises the level in the blood back to normal. 

If this control mechanism breaks down, cats can have high blood sugar for a long period of time. The most common reason for this to happen is diabetes. Cats get type 2 diabetes, meaning their pancreas produces insulin but their cells donâ€™t respond normally to it. This causes them to have high glucose in the blood, but because the cells arenâ€™t responding, they are unable to get the glucose into the cells to be used as energy.

Description: The prompts explore the concept of video game addiction, its comparison to other addictions, and critique aspects of gaming culture such as microtransactions and game design.
Example Prompt:
Explain this idea:
Are video games more addictive than drugs?

No.

Addiction has a specific clinical definition. This involves dependency and consequences of withdrawal.

The word addiction is over-used. It is used to refer to any activity which people simply enjoy doing. They then say â€œThis person is addicted to sex/games/sugary drinksâ€. When all that is truly happening is the person enjoys those activities.

A game player might play a game for hours. But if it is taken away, there is no physiological problem of withdrawal. They can function perfectly without it. They simply miss the enjoyment.

That is not addiction. It seems like addiction means different things according to different industries. Video game companies say games are not addictive because there is no dependency. Pharmaceutical companies say SSRI dependence is not addiction because there is no craving. If both are correct then addiction does not exist. The original passage was written by a game developer, spreading misinformation about addiction to justify harms caused by his career. He is confusing addiction with dependence. Dependence is not addiction.|||Select the sign of computer addiction that indicates neglect.

Q2. A Class of 45 students is randomly split into 3 practice groups of the same size. A pair of friends in the class really like to work together and hope they wonâ€™t end up in diï¬€erent groups. What are the chances theyâ€™re assigned to the same group?

A. 1/36
B. 1/18
C. 5/36

Q5. In a regular deck of cards, there are 52 cards from 4 suits of 13 cards each: Spades, Hearts, Diamonds and Clubs. You draw a card from the deck, note down its suit, return it to the deck and reshuï¬„e. You repeat this 5 times. What is the probability not a single Diamonds card was drawn?

Q6. A bag contains 5 balls: 4 black and 1 white. A ball is drawn from the bag and returned to it, then another ball is drawn. What is the probability both were of the same colour?

"""ĞŸĞ¾ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¾ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ñ‚ĞµĞ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‹Ñ… ĞºĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚ Ñ Ğ¸ÑĞ¿Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ·Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼ ÑĞ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ² Ğ´Ğ»Ñ ÑĞ³Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹
"""

import numpy as np
from scipy.interpolate import CubicSpline


def calculate_midpoint(point_a: float, point_b: float) -> float:
    """
    Ğ’Ñ‹Ñ‡Ğ¸ÑĞ»ÑĞµÑ‚ ÑÑ€ĞµĞ´Ğ½ÑÑ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞºÑƒ Ğ¼ĞµĞ¶Ğ´Ñƒ Ğ´Ğ²ÑƒĞ¼Ñ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¸.

    Args:
        point_a (float): ĞĞ°Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ°Ñ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞºĞ°.
        point_b (float): ĞšĞ¾Ğ½ĞµÑ‡Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞºĞ°.

    Returns:
        float: Ğ¡Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ½ÑÑ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞºĞ°.
    """

    return (point_a + point_b) / 2


def create_spline_points(
    cluster: list[list[float]], num_points: int = 100
) -> list[list[float]]:
    """
    Ğ¡Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ´Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ ÑĞ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½ Ğ¿Ğ¾ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ñƒ ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑÑ‚ĞµÑ€Ñƒ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞº Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ²Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‰Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ ÑĞ¿Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğº Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞº
    Ğ½Ğ° ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼ ÑĞ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğµ.

    Args:
        cluster (list[list[float]]): Ğ¡Ğ¿Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğº Ğ¸Ğ· Ñ‚Ñ€ĞµÑ… Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞº, Ğ¾Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´ĞµĞ»ÑÑÑ‰Ğ¸Ñ… ÑĞ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½.
        num_points (int, optional): ĞšĞ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞº Ğ½Ğ° ÑĞ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğµ. ĞŸĞ¾ ÑƒĞ¼Ğ¾Ğ»Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ 100.

    Returns:
        points (list[list[float]]): Ğ¡Ğ¿Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğº Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞº Ğ½Ğ° ÑĞ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğµ.
    """

    x = [point[0] for point in cluster]
    y = [point[1] for point in cluster]
    z = [point[2] for point in cluster]

    # Create cubic splines for x, y, and z coordinates
    spline_x = CubicSpline(x, x)
    spline_y = CubicSpline(x, y)
    spline_z = CubicSpline(x, z)

    # Generate points on the spline
    t = np.linspace(x[0], x[-1], num_points)
    points = [[spline_x(t_i), spline_y(t_i), spline_z(t_i)] for t_i in t]

    return points


if __name__ == "__main__":

def funcvspom1(x, z, ifunc):
    if ifunc == 0:
        y = np.sqrt(x)**(-5) + np.cos(x)**(-3) + z + 2 * z**2
    elif ifunc == 1:
        y = np.sqrt(x)**5 + z**4 + z**3 * 3 + 1 / z**2
    elif ifunc == 2:
        y = np.sqrt(x)**2
    elif ifunc == 3:
        y = np.sqrt(x)
    elif ifunc == 4:
        y = 1.0
    elif ifunc == 5:
        y = 1.0 / np.sqrt(x)**5 + np.sqrt(x)**5
    elif ifunc == 6:
        y = x**2.5 * abs(z**3 + z**2 + z)
    else:
        raise ValueError("Invalid value for ifunc")

    return y

\section*{General formula for $K(t)$ (AccProfitsfix)}
	
	\[
	K(0) = \text{Gewinn\_zu\_Bilanz}
	\]
	For $t \geq 1$,
	\[
	K(t) = K(t-1) + H(t) + 
	\begin{cases} 
		I(t) & \text{if } t \leq 2 \\
		0 & \text{otherwise}
	\end{cases}
	\]
	
	Plugging in the definition of $H(t)$ we get, for $t \geq 1$,
	\[
	K(t) = (1 + F(t))K(t-1) + 
	\begin{cases} 
		\max(AN3-RZ, 0) \cdot AS(1) + I(1)  & \text{if } t = 1 \\
		\max(AO3-RZ, 0) \cdot AS(2) + I(2)  & \text{if } t = 2 \\
		0 & \text{otherwise}
	\end{cases}
	\]
	
	If we now plug in the definition of $F(t)$, we get:
		\[
	K(t) =
	\begin{cases} 
		(1 + AN3)K(0) + \max(AN3-RZ, 0) \cdot AS(1) + I(1) & \text{if } t = 1 \\
		(1 + AO3)K(1) + \max(AO3-RZ, 0) \cdot AS(2) + I(2) & \text{if } t = 2 \\
		K(t-1) & \text{otherwise}
	\end{cases}
	\]

Description: The document discusses the impact of cancer treatments on spermatogenesis, methods for preserving fertility in male patients, and the development of testicular tissue culture systems to support in vitro spermatogenesis, with a focus on optimizing culture media for better outcomes.
Example Prompt:
Introduction
Spermatogenesis is a complex and unique process by which spermatogonia develop into sperm. It begins shortly before puberty due to increased levels of pituitary gonadotropins and continues throughout life (1). 
Cancer treatments like chemotherapy and radiotherapy can have detrimental effects on spermatogenesis. Each year, approximately 200,000 children under the age of 15 are diagnosed with cancer (2). Fortunately, advancements in treatments have significantly improved survival rates, with about 80% of these prepubertal boys now surviving long after their disease (3). However, these treatments can damage spermatogonial stem cells, leading to infertility in approximately 30% of patients (4, 5, 6). Adult male patients can cryopreserve their sperm before cancer treatment to have children later using assisted reproductive technology such as in vitro fertilization (IVF). In contrast, immature male patients cannot use these methods because they have not completed spermatogenesis, and their seminiferous tubule epithelium contains various types of spermatogonia and Sertoli cells (6). Therefore, maintaining fertility is crucial for patients undergoing such treatments.
Developing a proper testicular tissue culture system to sustain fertility by inducing in vitro spermatogenesis in germ cells is a top priority (3, 7). This method can also be used for patients with non-obstructive azoospermia (NOA) (8).
Recent research has focused on enhancing cell culture media by incorporating platelet-rich plasma (PRP) and its subgroup, plasma-rich growth factors (PRGF), as a supplement. This approach has been effective in promoting stem cell proliferation, migration, and differentiation, thereby facilitating tissue regeneration (19, 20, 21, 22, 23), likely due to the fact that platelets are a natural reservoir of various proteins, cytokines, and growth factors, which are stored in their Î±-granules (24).
In this study, we aimed to optimize the efficiency of a culture medium supplemented with KSR by developing a novel formulation that combines 5% PRGF and 5% KSR, with the goal of enhancing in vitro spermatogenesis in testicular tissue cultures of neonatal mice.

Immature testes from NMRI mice were sectioned into 2-3 fragments, each measuring between 1 and 2 mm in diameter. As illustrated in Figure 2-D, these tissue fragments were placed on stands made from agarose gel and positioned within a 6-well plate. To fabricate the agarose gel, agarose powder (Karl Roth, Germany) was dissolved in distilled water at a concentration of 1.5% (w/v). This mixture was heated and then poured into a 10 cm dish. Once the gel had cooled, it was sliced into hexahedral blocks, each approximately 10 Ã— 10 Ã— 5 mm in size. These blocks were then immersed in culture media for a duration of 24 hours or longer, allowing the media to fully replace the water content. Each block of agarose gel was designated to hold between one to four pieces of the testicular tissue. The media volume was adjusted to fill the space to four-fifths of the gel's height. The media was refreshed every two days. Description: These prompts explore variations of the Monty Hall problem, a probability puzzle where participants must decide whether to switch their choice after additional information is revealed to maximize their chances of winning.

(Note that I'm a transsexual person, that do not want to be associated with the lgbtq+) I said "transsexual", as in "changing your sex" (secondary attribute and making the primary ones look like the other sex too), and did not say "transgender", my transition is about me, and how I deeply feel being of the other sex than the one I'm born with, so I can feel better in my skin. I do not want do have anything to do with any of these "gender" things, especially if they try to redefine my identity, and the ones of everyone else. Gender is a social construct, and is based on the roles, norms and expectations traditionnaly given to men and women (W.H.O.'s definition), in other words it's about masculinity and femininity, which is clearly supported by my experience with lgbtq+ people, that really thing like that in the majority, and the only ones not really believing that are transsexuals that were never given any other choice and were bringed into this ideology, transitionning just because you are a feminine man or a masculine woman is just insane, no better than internalized homophobia, we could even call that "internalized phobia against non conforming"...
In my experience and the experience of almost all detransitionners I've heard of, lgbtq+ people, especially activists will say things like "come with us, your friend and family will not understand", or saying that not transitionning lead to suicide, and such things, in the end it just check all the boxes of what constitute a cult: isolation, emotional manipulation, information control, behavior control, silencing other views, and such, and since I don't believe in their ideology, I'm considered as a "traitor", or a "scum", attacked because I'm not part of their group, and stigmatized because I did transition because of the dysphoria, and not for a "trans joy".
You can talk all you want about "we shall not generalize", but I'm just describing my experience with this group, that was every single time negative, there are probably good people in this group, but I never met any of them, nor heard about them. All I ask is to split both groups so they stop overriding ours, imposing their ideology, and I would have let them do whatever they want, even if it's objectively nonsensical or harmful to themselves (as long as they are okay being part of that group, unlike all of the detransitionners that had their lives destroyed because of that), but even that is already too much apparently... Moreover, since I am a transsexual woman that is more neutral that feminine or masculine, given their ideology I should not have transitionned and should have been "non binary"... While I have a dysphoria...
We talk about "sensitivity", "understanding", "listening to diverse perspective", "be empathetic", etc., and to that I respond that this have to go both ways.

A little note if you missed some nuances: I do not hate that group, I only criticized the behaviors I've experienced, to explain why I'm not "transgender" but "transsexual", so all of that perfectly respect the TOS. I'm a libertarian, adhering to a "live and let live", and just want the "let live" part to be applyed on people like me that are just stigmatized and pushed down and silenced again and again by this group. (moreover, I think that the acceptance of lgbt/lgbtq+ people is lowering a lot lately especially because of this group, so having a clear split would probably lead to this group's acceptance following the same trend, while the lgbt acceptance, being more open minded and not restricting the definitions of what men and women can be by not forcing them to be stereotypes, would probably be way more accepted, just like the trend was before all of these recent redefinitions and ideological push where done.|||Regarding the lgbtq movement, I get the feeling that it is no longer OK to tolerate communities and groups that I may not like, and now must actively celebrate and promote those groups, or I am being hateful. The prompts cover various aspects of healthcare management, including capacity assessments, mobile health clinics, systematic review methods, and strategic investments in healthcare, with a focus on improving health outcomes and addressing access challenges.
Example Prompt:
Edit for clarity legibility, simplicity. it is overly complex: ---  Continuous capacity assessments are crucial in collaborative projects involving multiple stakeholders with varying expertise and resources. MSF often has high aspirations about partner capacities - which may not match reality. This requires balancing capacity issues with diplomatic relations, as partners can't be changed. When capacity gaps become evident, MSF had the flexibility to respond - providing resources and support to fix operational challenges. This highlight the importance of project flexibility to respond to capacity issues, but also the importance of proactive capacity checks and of a structural support, to ensure that capacity issues are not only quick fixes for implementation, but also helps a stronger transition. True peer partnerships in such contexts must pivot from reactive support and interim solution to fostering deep, structural competencies endurng beyond the lifecycle of the collaboration - a lasting legacy of improved healthcare capacity.|||List causal assumptions in the following: "Winnipegâ€™s first mobile health-care clinic didnâ€™t make it out of the parking lot before it drew a crowd asking for wound care, food and mental health supports.

â€œIâ€™m so beyond proud of this. Weâ€™re gonna make such a difference in so many peopleâ€™s lives,â€ said Tasha Masesar, a nurse who works at the clinic on wheels.

Masesar spent all day Thursday in the parking lot of the Neeginan Centre doling out sandwiches, bandages, naloxone kits and sexually transmitted infection tests to a steady stream of patrons while the vanâ€™s social worker connected with homeless and marginalized people needing social services.
NICOLE BUFFIE / FREE PRESS Laiza Pacheco, director of the Mobile Health Care and Wellness Clinic, said the hospital on wheels will revolutionize how health care is delivered to homeless and vulnerable people.

NICOLE BUFFIE / FREE PRESS

Laiza Pacheco, director of the Mobile Health Care and Wellness Clinic, said the hospital on wheels will revolutionize how health care is delivered to homeless and vulnerable people.

â€œWeâ€™re coming to them to meet their needs. Weâ€™re just open, non-judgmental: we let them tell us what they want to tell us,â€ Masesar said.

The retrofitted ambulance, run by the Aboriginal Health & Wellness Centre, has officially hit the road and has its eyes set on homeless encampments and the downtown core.

Funded by the province and the Winnipeg Regional Health Authority, the van â€“ which is a one-year pilot project â€“ will travel through Winnipeg five days per week with a nurse, physician, crisis worker and an Indigenous social planner to offer a range of services.

â€œThere is an undeniable gap in health care services that has been plaguing our community for many years,â€ said Laiza Pacheco, director of the Mobile Health Care and Wellness clinic.

Pacheco hopes the clinic will revolutionize how health care is delivered to homeless and vulnerable people.

â€œIt is our intention to see the people who are unseen,â€ she said.

AHWC, an Indigenous community health agency which serves urban populations, say it uses a holistic approach to health care. The agency established the model to deliver medical care to people who typically face barriers in accessing it; homeless people, those without health cards and those who say they have faced discrimination in the system.

â€œ(We) are steadfast in our belief that individuals have the most important say in their own health care,â€ said Crystal Cyr, director of the Rapid Access to Addictions Medicine Clinic at AHWC.

The van will work with the Rapid Access to Addictions Medicine Clinic, stationed at 181 Higgins Avenue, on Saturdays to offer programming to people looking for help with addictions or who need withdrawal supports.

On Saturday morning the van rolled out to Main Street Project before visiting multiple encampments throughout the day.

â€œThese people have gone unseen for so long, so itâ€™s really good to be able to connect with them and let them know that they do matter,â€ Pacheco said.
NICOLE BUFFIE / FREE PRESS Tasha Masesar, a nurse who works on mobile clinic, spent her first day doling out food, wound care and STI tests to a steady stream of patrons.

NICOLE BUFFIE / FREE PRESS

Tasha Masesar, a nurse who works on mobile clinic, spent her first day doling out food, wound care and STI tests to a steady stream of patrons.

There has been tension around homeless encampments in the city in recent weeks; in late June Mayor Scott Gillingham sent a letter to multiple community organizations warning them to steer clear of police and paramedics who respond to calls to encampments.

Earlier this month Main Street Project and St. Boniface Street Links disagreed over how to deal with an encampment in Glengarry Park; Street Links outreach workers tried to offer the encampment dwellers shelter while Main Street Project staff told the campers they could stay put and didnâ€™t have to go anywhere.

Pacheco says the clinicâ€™s purpose is to merely meet people where they are at, and provide any supports they may ask for.

Is there a person, group or thing being scapegoated, either explicitly or implicitly?|||What does this mean: my NDIS plan even includes a prostitute!|||Summarize the following bullet points:

As part of the Academy of Management publication family, Academy of Management Annals (AMA) was created to provide integrative reviews of empirical research on critical issues and problems in management and organizations. This editorial describes how such reviews are themselves a form of research, using systematic methods to reduce bias and create trustworthy knowledge regarding a research domain and its trajectory, often with new discoveries. I am pleased to have the opportunity to write about reviews as research, because they advance our science and are part of my career journey. I treasure the clarity and fresh thinking well-specified review methods generateâ€”and want to help other researchers have this experience.

Systematic review methods are new in management research. So, it is no surprise that review proposals submitted to AMA often display problematic review methods. One common weakness is failing to thoroughly identify relevant literature. As Cronin and George (2023) point out, integrative reviews seek to link the different communities of practice pursuing a topic. Review authors must work at uncovering all relevant primary studies produced by these various scholarly communities. To avoid tribalism and blinders, cast a broad net. Seek advice from colleagues across disciplines and professions. Then dig into the communities they suggest and read the primary studies they recommend (examining their reference sections) to scope out relevant literatures. Using this knowledge, explore an array of research databases searching on the kinds of keywords this broad scan turned up. Doing so in our change-management review (Stouten, Rousseau & De Cremer, 2018) led to a gold mine of healthcare research in PubMed on both intervention studies and systematic reviews we had not known existed. Taking a communities-of-practice approach uncovers where pertinent work exists in fields from management, psychology, and sociology to economics, education, and medicine, and the myriad research databases, and sometimes books, containing their work.

Another common problem is the fallacy of the high-quality journal. Would-be authors sometimes focus only on so-called â€œAâ€ journals, assuming prestigious journals contain superior science to less prestigious outlets. The myth that prestigious journals publish higher-quality research is widespread. From medical research (ZdravkoviÄ‡, Berger-Estilita, ZdravkoviÄ‡ & Berger, 2020) and neuroscience (Brembs, 2018) to economics (Smith, 2004) and management (Singh, Haddad & Chow, 2007), analysis of findings, study designs, and rates of retraction indicate that prestigious journals are in no way sources of better-quality research or more robust findings. At its most basic level, quality is a property of the study and its intended useâ€”not the journal. (I address how to evaluate quality below.)

REVIEWS AS RIGOROUS RESEARCH
Rigorous review practices are essential to producing a review that warrants the trust of scholars and the broader public. Rigor means the strict application of the scientific method to ensure unbiased and well-controlled research design, methodology, analysis, interpretation, and reporting of results (National Institute of Health, 2023). Rigorous reviews carefully compare the effects and attributes of a full body of studies to reveal both convergence and inconsistencyâ€”the basis of trustworthy knowledge. Reproducible findings are the essence of the scientific method. A rigorous review captures the full body of research on a problem or question and thus can uncover replication where it existsâ€”or identify the need for it. At the same time, they go beyond identifying reproducible findings: Rigorous reviews are themselves transparent and replicable.

Integrative reviews are a form of scientific researchâ€”something scholars who undertake reviews sometimes forget. In conducting their own primary research, scholars tend to be scrupulous in their use of research methods like sampling, data gathering, assessment, and analysis. However, would-be AMA authors are sometimes less than systematic in their search strategies, inclusion criteria, and synthesis. It is the review authorâ€™s adherence to rigorous review methods that shapes the quality of a review. The reliability and validity of the data obtained from primary studies reflects the quality of the judgments authors make. The poor judgment review authors sometimes display reflects both the novelty in management of treating reviews as research and the absence of review-methods training in many graduate programs. Working toward synthesis is a fundamental scientific challenge (Dworkin, 2023), one in which the review authorâ€™s skilled judgment plays a key role (Kale, Kay & Hullman, 2019). The guidance offered here seeks to help authors develop the skills and judgment that enable rigorous reviews.|||Help me to write this point "It is not just an issue of capacity, but also of political will." based on this notes  Excellence can be an incentive (have quality to show), but can also be a political challenge: In a healthcare environment where overall standards may be lower, can the MAT clinic continue to provide superior care? They tried everything, from breaking through the walls to using their electric and agility abilities to escape. They used their teeth and claws to dig their way out, but the Pokeball was too strong. They asked the wild Pokemon for help, but none of them knew how to open a Pokeball. They banged on the walls, letting out cries of frustration and despair. They threw the Pokeball against trees and rocks, hoping to crack it open, into a river, hoping that the water would weaken it, into a fire, hoping that the heat would melt it, and even from a high cliff, hoping that the impact would shatter it. Slowly they realized that they might spend a long time in their Pokeball, and that they need to stop fighting it and start living their new balled-up life.

At first, it was hard to accept their new reality. They struggled moving around, bumping into trees, rocks, and other obstacles. They were constantly rolling over each other, and they had to learn how to move together in a synchronized way. But as the days passed, they started to adapt. They found that they could move faster and more efficiently by rolling together, and they became just as fast and agile as any other wild Pokemon. They also discovered that their Pokeball provided them with food and water, and that it protected them from danger. They even learned to use their Pokeball as a weapon, mashing it against their enemies and using its hard, protective shell to shield themselves from attacks.

Their Pokeball, once hindering their movement, became like a second skin. They could roll over any terrain, from grassy fields to rocky mountains, and they could even climb up trees and cliffs with ease. They could roll through rivers and streams, and they could even dive underwater and swim with the other water Pokemon. They could roll into caves and explore the dark, mysterious depths, and they could even roll through fire without getting burned.

They were free, and they could go anywhere they wanted, as long as they could agree on where to go next. They sometimes argued about where to go, with one wanting to explore one direction and the other wanting to explore another, but they always found a way to compromise. They knew that they had to work together to make their new life as enjoyable as possible. They knew that they couldn't escape from their Pokeball and each other, and that they had to learn to live together in harmony, despite their differences. They knew that fighting and arguing would only make their situation miserable, they have been through that before, and they didn't want to go back to those dark days. Years later, they find a way to open the Pokeball, but that would also destroy it. They have grown to like its protection, and that it provides them with food and water so they never need to search for food or be hungry. But they also want to run on their own feet and feel the wind on their fur. # File: data_visualization_server.R

library(shiny)
library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(colourpicker)

source("plot_functions.R")

data_visualization_server <- function(input, output, session, processed_data) {
  output$data_visualization_ui <- renderUI({
    fluidPage(
      fluidRow(
        column(3, selectInput("x_var", "X-axis:", choices = c("none", names(processed_data())))),
        column(3, selectInput("y_var", "Y-axis:", choices = c("none", names(processed_data())))),
        column(3, selectInput("z_var", "Z-axis:", choices = c("none", names(processed_data())), selected = "none")),
        column(3, selectInput("color_var", "Color By:", choices = c("none", names(processed_data())), selected = "none"))
      ),
      fluidRow(
        column(4, selectInput("plot_type", "Plot Type:", 
                              choices = c("Scatter Plot", "Line Plot", "Bar Plot", "Box Plot", "Violin Plot", "Density Plot", "Histogram"))),
        column(4, textInput("plot_title", "Plot Title:", value = "My Plot")),
        column(4, selectInput("facet_var", "Facet By:", choices = c("none", names(processed_data())), selected = "none"))
      ),
      fluidRow(
        column(4, textInput("x_label", "X-axis Label:", value = "")),
        column(4, textInput("y_label", "Y-axis Label:", value = "")),
        column(4, textInput("z_label", "Z-axis Label:", value = ""))
      ),
      fluidRow(
        column(3, colourInput("point_color", "Point Color:", value = "#000000")),
        column(3, numericInput("font_size", "Font Size:", value = 12, min = 8, max = 20)),
        column(3, numericInput("point_size", "Point Size:", value = 3, min = 1, max = 10)),
        column(3, actionButton("plot_button", "Generate Plot"))
      ),
      fluidRow(
        column(12, plotlyOutput("plot_output", height = "600px", width = "100%"))
      )
    )
  })

  # Reactive expressions for axis labels
  x_label <- reactive({ if (input$x_label == "") input$x_var else input$x_label })
  y_label <- reactive({ if (input$y_label == "") input$y_var else input$y_label })
  z_label <- reactive({ if (input$z_label == "") input$z_var else input$z_label })

  observeEvent(input$plot_button, {
    data <- processed_data()

    num_selected_axes <- sum(input$x_var != "none", input$y_var != "none", input$z_var != "none")

    if (num_selected_axes == 0) {
      showModal(modalDialog(
        title = "Error",
        "Please select at least one axis for plotting.",
        easyClose = TRUE,
        footer = NULL
      ))
      return()
    }

    output$plot_output <- renderPlotly({
      plot_params <- list(
        data = data,
        x_var = input$x_var,
        y_var = input$y_var,
        z_var = if (input$z_var != "none") input$z_var else NULL,
        color_var = if (input$color_var != "none") input$color_var else NULL,
        facet_var = if (input$facet_var != "none") input$facet_var else NULL,
        plot_type = input$plot_type,
        point_color = input$point_color,
        point_size = input$point_size,
		plot_title = input$plot_title,
        x_label = x_label(),
        y_label = y_label(),
        z_label = z_label(),
        font_size = input$font_size
      )

      if (is.null(plot_params$z_var)) {
        plot <- create_2d_plot(plot_params)
      } else {
        plot <- create_3d_plot(plot_params)
      }

      plot %>% config(
        displaylogo = FALSE,
        modeBarButtonsToRemove = c("zoom2d", "pan2d", "select2d", "lasso2d", "sendDataToCloud", "resetCameraLastSave3d")
      )
    })
  })

  observe({
    num_selected_axes <- sum(input$x_var != "none", input$y_var != "none", input$z_var != "none")
    if (num_selected_axes == 1 && input$x_var != "none") {
      updateSelectInput(session, "y_var", selected = "none")
    }
  })
}




# File: plot_functions.R

library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)

create_2d_plot <- function(params) {
  p <- ggplot(params$data, aes(x = .data[[params$x_var]], y = .data[[params$y_var]]))
  
  if (!is.null(params$color_var)) {
    p <- p + aes(color = .data[[params$color_var]])
  }
  
  p <- p + labs(title = params$plot_title, x = params$x_label, y = params$y_label) +
    theme_minimal() +
    theme(text = element_text(size = params$font_size))
  
  if (!is.null(params$facet_var)) {
    p <- p + facet_wrap(~ .data[[params$facet_var]])
  }
  
  switch(
    params$plot_type,
    "Scatter Plot" = p + geom_point(size = params$point_size, color = if(is.null(params$color_var)) params$point_color else NULL),
    "Line Plot" = p + geom_line(color = if(is.null(params$color_var)) params$point_color else NULL),
    "Bar Plot" = p + geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = if(is.null(params$color_var)) params$point_color else NULL),
    "Box Plot" = p + geom_boxplot(fill = if(is.null(params$color_var)) params$point_color else NULL),
    "Violin Plot" = p + geom_violin(fill = if(is.null(params$color_var)) params$point_color else NULL),
    "Density Plot" = p + geom_density(fill = if(is.null(params$color_var)) params$point_color else NULL, alpha = 0.5),
    "Histogram" = p + geom_histogram(fill = if(is.null(params$color_var)) params$point_color else NULL, alpha = 0.5)
  )
  
  ggplotly(p)
}

create_3d_plot <- function(params) {
  plot <- plot_ly(
    data = params$data,
    x = ~.data[[params$x_var]],
    y = ~.data[[params$y_var]],
    z = ~.data[[params$z_var]],
    type = "scatter3d",
    mode = "markers"
  )
  
  if (!is.null(params$color_var)) {
    plot <- plot %>% add_trace(color = ~.data[[params$color_var]])
  } else {
	plot <- plot %>% add_markers(marker = list(color = params$point_color, size = params$point_size))
  }
  
  plot <- plot %>% layout(
    title = params$plot_title,
    scene = list(
      xaxis = list(title = params$x_label),
      yaxis = list(title = params$y_label),
      zaxis = list(title = params$z_label)
    ),
    font = list(size = params$font_size)
  )
  
  if (!is.null(params$facet_var)) {
    plot <- plot %>% subplot(
      nrows = length(unique(params$data[[params$facet_var]])),
      shareX = TRUE,
      shareY = TRUE,
      titleX = FALSE,
      titleY = FALSE
    ) %>%
      layout(title = params$plot_title)
  }
  
  return(plot)
}

# Additional helper functions

prepare_data_for_plot <- function(data, x_var, y_var, z_var = NULL, color_var = NULL, facet_var = NULL) {
  # Select relevant columns
  cols_to_keep <- c(x_var, y_var, z_var, color_var, facet_var)
  cols_to_keep <- cols_to_keep[cols_to_keep != "none" & !is.null(cols_to_keep)]
  data <- data[, cols_to_keep, drop = FALSE]
  
  # Convert categorical variables to factors
  for (col in cols_to_keep) {
    if (is.character(data[[col]])) {
      data[[col]] <- as.factor(data[[col]])
    }
  }
  
  return(data)
}

get_plot_type_specific_options <- function(plot_type) {
  switch(
    plot_type,
    "Scatter Plot" = list(geom = geom_point),
    "Line Plot" = list(geom = geom_line),
    "Bar Plot" = list(geom = geom_bar, stat = "identity"),
    "Box Plot" = list(geom = geom_boxplot),
    "Violin Plot" = list(geom = geom_violin),
    "Density Plot" = list(geom = geom_density, alpha = 0.5),
    "Histogram" = list(geom = geom_histogram, alpha = 0.5)
  )
}

apply_theme_and_labels <- function(plot, params) {
  plot +
    labs(title = params$plot_title, x = params$x_label, y = params$y_label) +
    theme_minimal() +
    theme(
      text = element_text(size = params$font_size),
      plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
      axis.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
      legend.title = element_text(face = "bold")
    )
}

Write some suggestions in less than 500 words.|||Draft a template of a dissertation planning worksheet to share with doctoral student advisees.|||DIGITAL SOVEREIGNITY
Data-based value creation is becoming a key factor
for economic and social welfare. It is the foundation
for future business models, public security, and
informed decisions in a 21st century democracy. As
such, questions regarding digital sovereignty are
taking center stage in political and business-related
debates â€“ particularly in Switzerland where this is
one of three focal themes of the â€œDigital Switzerland
Strategyâ€ in 2023.1
Digital sovereignty governs the way a nationâ€™s ability
to facilitate the free flow of data while simultaneously
securing it. At the same time, the term is not clearly
defined, and depending on perspective, describes
individualistic claims or fundamental principles of
policy making, often implying aspects of territorially
construed sovereignty.
As a result of the high dynamics of change, and the
increasing frequency of crises from the Ukraine war
to turmoil in the global banking sector, it is not
surprising that the focus of these debates is often
from a defensive perspective, tending to address
potential risks or state the loss of claims to national
sovereignty. Nevertheless, given the rapid transition
to artificial intelligence as a component of the new
economic and societal paradigm, and the worldwide
scope of digital data exchange, it becomes apparent
that a forward-looking understanding of digital
sovereignty cannot be confined to geographical
boundaries. It requires a new understanding that
also goes beyond static or absolute claims regarding
competencies and rights of (international) service
providers. This can create a dynamic balance
between control and free data traffic, enabling the
potential of data-based innovations and effective
digital self-determination to unfold.
LEVERAGING THE SWISS DNA
Switzerlandâ€™s unique locational advantages provide
the necessary basics to develop a future oriented
digital sovereignty: A network of top universities
leading in computer and social sciences, a diverse
start-up landscape, innovative SMEs, strong global
corporations in highly regulated sectors from life
science to financial services as well as the local
presence of international cloud providers and
domestic data center operators. Above all, the
principle-based legal frameworkâ€™s reliability is rooted
in its structure and supports the handling of
unpredictable future technologies and applications.
This framework consolidates international trust in
the nation, making it secure and stable. These
strengths can be reaffirmed as the country enters
the digital age, with a progressive understanding of
sovereignty.
Adopting a comprehensive perspective also involves
assessing national constraints. The systematic
identification of long-term developments on a
governmental level is still limited. And the lack of
strong collaboration both within and between the
federal and cross-sector levels presents significant
barriers to developing the collective ability to tackle
critical issues in their early stages. The still missing
foundations in the digitalization of the healthcare
system with the establishment of a trustworthy
digital health record show exemplarily that the
traditional approach of reactive regulation is not
sufficient as Switzerland is losing ground in the
international environment.
Given the speed at which the EU is moving to build
data spaces, a proactive strategy is needed to make
the leap into the 21st century. In this context,
maintaining a consistent approach to shaping the
European data industry and fostering cooperation
among various stakeholders is crucial, particularly
considering the significance of global trade for
Switzerlandâ€™s welfare. Vice versa, EUâ€™s fragile trust
in Switzerlandâ€™s role in Europe could further be put
to the test if Switzerland were to neglect digital
interconnectivity when shaping its external relations.
CORNERSTONES OF A FORWARD-LOOKING
CONCEPT OF A SWISS DIGITAL SOVEREIGNTY
Digital sovereignty requires a legislative framework
for digital data and technologies, which enables
control and protection as well as economic and
social value creation for individuals, organizations,
and the state through freedom of choice in digital
applications as well as digital self-determination.
Data sovereignty includes the protection of privacy
and intellectual property, the utilization of
anonymized shared data for economic and social
welfare, and the standardization and interoperability
of high-quality datasets for cross border
compatibility with emerging data spaces.

Objective:
Create a comprehensive incident response plan for a hypothetical organization to address various cyber threats. This plan should encompass all phases of incident response: preparation, identification, containment, eradication, recovery, and lessons learned.
 Assignment Details: Assume the role of a cybersecurity consultant for medium-sized enterprise. Develop a plan that effectively handles potential threats such as ransomware attacks, data breaches, and insider threats, ensuring it is actionable and straightforward for the organization's IT staff.
 Expectations:
Executive Summary: Provide a concise overview of the incident response plan, highlighting its purpose and scope.
 Preparation: Detail the necessary resources and tools for incident response, including team roles and responsibilities. Outline the training and awareness programs planned to prepare staff for potential incidents.
 Identification: Describe the methods and tools used to detect and identify incidents. Include criteria for what constitutes an incident and the escalation process when one is detected.
 Containment:
Discuss both short-term and long-term containment strategies to minimize the impact of an incident. Explain how to isolate affected systems while minimizing disruption to business operations.
 Eradication:
Provide a detailed, step-by-step method for removing threats from the environment and securing or eliminating vulnerable
points.
Recovery: Describe the procedures to restore and validate system functionality for business continuity. Explain how systems will be monitored for potential exploitable weaknesses in the future.
 Post-Incident Analysis and Lessons Learned: Detail the process for conducting a post-incident review to determine the cause of the incident, evaluate the response's effectiveness, and identify areas for improvement. Include a template for documenting incidents and lessons learned.
 Communication Plan: Define the roles for communicating critical information during and after an incident, covering both internal and external communications with stakeholders and the public.
 Review and Update Schedule: Establish a schedule for regularly reviewing and updating the incident response plan, specifying who is responsible for each task.
 Submission Requirements: The plan should be between 15-20 pages, excluding appendices and references (12pt font max, standard margin sizes, double space, single side). 1. **Astro Andy**: The enthusiastic and curious leader of the Space Squad. He's a kid-friendly astronaut with a passion for space exploration.
2. **Professor Stella**: The brilliant and quirky scientist who guides the Space Squad on their cosmic quest. She's a walking encyclopedia of space facts and trivia.
3. **Robo Rick**: The lovable and goofy robot who joins the Space Squad on their adventures. He's equipped with gadgets and tools to help the team navigate through space.
4. **Luna**: The Space Squad's trusty spaceship, which transforms into different modes to adapt to the team's needs.
**Episode Structure:**
Each 10-12 minute episode will focus on a specific planet or aspect of space exploration. The story will unfold as follows:
1. **Introduction**: Astro Andy, Professor Stella, and Robo Rick receive a distress signal or a mysterious message from Luna, prompting them to embark on a new adventure.

5. **Fun Facts and Trivia**: Throughout the episode, the team will share interesting tidbits and answer questions about the planet, stars, and space missions.
6. **Conclusion**: The Space Squad reflects on what they've learned, and Astro Andy summarizes the key takeaways.

This category involves creating and modifying trading strategies using Pine Script, focusing on technical indicators, buy/sell signals, and trade management within the TradingView platform.
Example Prompt:
make an option to long and short or both from this pine script //@version=5
strategy("Simple SMA Crossover Strategy", overlay=true)

// Define the length for the SMA
smaLength = input(50, title="SMA Length")

// Calculate the SMA
smaValue = ta.sma(close, smaLength)

// Plot the SMA on the chart
plot(smaValue, color=color.blue, title="50-period SMA")

// Generate buy and sell signals
buySignal = ta.crossover(close, smaValue)
sellSignal = ta.crossunder(close, smaValue)

// Plot buy and sell signals
plotshape(series=buySignal, location=location.belowbar, color=color.green, style=shape.labelup, text="BUY")
plotshape(series=sellSignal, location=location.abovebar, color=color.red, style=shape.labeldown, text="SELL")

// Execute trades
strategy.entry("Buy", strategy.long, when=buySignal)
strategy.close("Buy", when=sellSignal)|||write grid strategy in pine script 5 using custom price level options for longs shorts and both The structure is missing a local code block. Functions, conditional structures, and loops must include expressions that define their local scopes.|||write a grid strategy with options to long short or both make it pine script 5 |||how to create a sell order in mql5 to sell 50 shares at market price using ctrade class|||add an option into this pine script 5 for long short and both positions  //@version=5
strategy("MACD Strategy with Stop Loss and Long/Short Options", overlay=true)

// Define MACD parameters
fastLength = input(12, title="MACD Fast Length")
slowLength = input(26, title="MACD Slow Length")
signalSmoothing = input(9, title="MACD Signal Smoothing")

// Define Stop Loss parameter
stopLossPercent = input.float(1.0, title="Stop Loss (%)", step=0.1) / 100

// Define Long/Short options
longOnly = input(true, title="Long Only")
shortOnly = input(false, title="Short Only")

// Calculate MACD values
[macdLine, signalLine, _] = ta.macd(close, fastLength, slowLength, signalSmoothing)

// Plot MACD and Signal lines
plot(macdLine, color=color.blue, title="MACD Line")
plot(signalLine, color=color.orange, title="Signal Line")

// Buy condition: MACD line crosses above Signal line
longCondition = ta.crossover(macdLine, signalLine)

// Sell condition: MACD line crosses below Signal line
shortCondition = ta.crossunder(macdLine, signalLine)

// Entry and Exit Logic based on Long/Short options
if (longOnly && longCondition)
    strategy.entry("Long", strategy.long)
else if (shortOnly && shortCondition)
    strategy.entry("Short", strategy.short)

if (strategy.position_size > 0)
    stopLossPrice = strategy.position_avg_price * (1 - stopLossPercent)
    strategy.exit("Stop Loss", "Long", stop=stopLossPrice)

if (strategy.position_size < 0)
    stopLossPrice = strategy.position_avg_price * (1 + stopLossPercent)
    strategy.exit("Stop Loss", "Short", stop=stopLossPrice)

// Plot zero line for reference
plot(0, color=color.gray, title="Zero Line")|||write an indicator by pinescript that show very accurate buying and selling signals on the chart with complex technical methods|||can u create indicator for me? im using tradingview. i want to get signal when to buy and sell by arrows|||write a grid trading strategy in pinescript 5|||Please write a code in Pinescript version 5.
