|||Ğ£Ğ»ÑƒÑ‡ÑˆĞ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½ÑƒÑ ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ĞµĞ³Ğ¸Ñ, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ€ĞµĞ¹Ñ‚ Ğ±Ñ‹Ğ» Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ 
//@version=5
strategy("TEST", overlay=true, max_lines_count=500, max_labels_count=500)

// Constants and Inputs
var float SCR = 0.
var float ATR = 0.
var bool TradeOn = false
var float Res = 0.

color GREEN = color.rgb(4, 191, 101)
color RED = color.rgb(246, 7, 7)
color _Green = color.rgb(2, 106, 89)
color TAIL = color.rgb(20, 141, 154)

bool Filter = input.bool(false, "ATR Body Filter", group="Core Settings")
float Target = input.float(1.3, "Target", step=0.1, tooltip="Target And stop Multiplyer", group="Core Settings")
bool SLType = input.string('Close', 'SL Type', ['Close', 'High/Low'], group="Core Settings") == 'Close'
float Risk = input.float(100, "Risk Per Trade (USD)", group="Core Settings")
bool ShowSL = input.bool(false, "Show SL", group="Core Settings")

var bool TradeisON = false
var bool LongTrade = false
var bool ShortTrade = false
var float TP = 0.0
var float SL = 0.0

// Streak counters
var int currentWinStreak = 0
var int currentLossStreak = 0
var int maxWinStreak = 0
var int maxLossStreak = 0

// Variables for lines and labels
var line tpLine = na
var line SLLine = na
var label LAB = na

// Functions
volAdj(len) => math.min(ta.atr(len) * 0.3, close * (0.3/100))[20] / 2
BodyRange() => math.abs(close - open)

PF = volAdj(30)
BodyCon = bar_index > 100
BodyCon1 = (Filter ? BodyRange() < ta.atr(5) * 1 : true)

// Daily calculations
if timeframe.change("1D") and not TradeisON
    ATR := volAdj(30)
    SCR := hl2 - (ATR * 15)
    TradeOn := true
    Res := SCR + (ATR * 25)

// Entry conditions
BUY = ta.crossover(close[1], Res) and BodyCon and BodyCon1
SELL = ta.crossunder(close[1], SCR) and BodyCon and BodyCon1

// SL Calculation
longDiffSL = math.abs(close - SCR)
longDiffSL2 = math.abs(close - Res)

// Trade logic
Long = BUY and not TradeisON
Short = SELL and not TradeisON
TradeFire = Long or Short

if Long and not TradeisON
    LongTrade := true
    ShortTrade := false

if Short and not TradeisON
    LongTrade := false
    ShortTrade := true

if TradeFire and not TradeisON
    TP := Long ? close + (Target * longDiffSL) : close - (Target * longDiffSL2)
    SL := Long ? close - longDiffSL : close + longDiffSL2
    TradeisON := true
    
    // Create lines and labels for target and stop loss
    if Long
        line.new(bar_index, high, bar_index, TP, width=2, color=TAIL, style=line.style_dashed)
        tpLine := line.new(bar_index, TP, bar_index + 2, TP, style=line.style_dashed, color=TAIL)
        if ShowSL     
            SLLine := line.new(bar_index, SL, bar_index + 2, SL, style=line.style_dashed, color=RED)
        LAB := label.new(bar_index, TP, "Target", color=TAIL, style=label.style_label_left, size=size.small, textcolor=color.white)
    else
        line.new(bar_index, low, bar_index, TP, width=2, color=TAIL, style=line.style_dashed)
        tpLine := line.new(bar_index, TP, bar_index + 2, TP, style=line.style_dashed, color=TAIL)
        if ShowSL     
            SLLine := line.new(bar_index, SL, bar_index + 2, SL, style=line.style_dashed, color=RED)
        LAB := label.new(bar_index, TP, "Target", color=TAIL, style=label.style_label_left, size=size.small, textcolor=color.white)
    
    if Long
        strategy.entry("Long", strategy.long)
    else
        strategy.entry("Short", strategy.short)

// Exit logic
if LongTrade and TradeisON
    if high >= TP
        strategy.close("Long", comment="TP")
        TradeisON := false
        currentWinStreak += 1
        currentLossStreak := 0
        if currentWinStreak > maxWinStreak
            maxWinStreak := currentWinStreak
        label.set_color(LAB, GREEN)
    if (SLType ? close : low) <= SL
        strategy.close("Long", comment="SL")
        TradeisON := false
        currentLossStreak += 1
        currentWinStreak := 0
        if currentLossStreak > maxLossStreak
            maxLossStreak := currentLossStreak
        label.set_color(LAB, color.new(RED, 70))
        label.set_tooltip(LAB, "Stoploss Hit : " + str.tostring(math.round_to_mintick(SL)))

if ShortTrade and TradeisON
    if low <= TP
        strategy.close("Short", comment="TP")
        TradeisON := false
        currentWinStreak += 1
        currentLossStreak := 0
        if currentWinStreak > maxWinStreak
            maxWinStreak := currentWinStreak
        label.set_color(LAB, GREEN)
    if (SLType ? close : high) >= SL
        strategy.close("Short", comment="SL")
        TradeisON := false
        currentLossStreak += 1
        currentWinStreak := 0
        if currentLossStreak > maxLossStreak
            maxLossStreak := currentLossStreak
        label.set_color(LAB, color.new(RED, 70))
        label.set_tooltip(LAB, "Stoploss Hit : " + str.tostring(math.round_to_mintick(SL)))

// Update lines and labels
if TradeisON
    line.set_x2(tpLine, bar_index)
    label.set_x(LAB, bar_index + 1)
    if ShowSL
        line.set_x2(SLLine, bar_index)

// Plotting
plotshape(Long, title="Long Entry", location=location.belowbar, color=GREEN, style=shape.triangleup, size=size.small)
plotshape(Short, title="Short Entry", location=location.abovebar, color=RED, style=shape.triangledown, size=size.small)

plot(Res, "Resistance", color=color.purple, linewidth=2)
plot(SCR, "Support", color=color.purple, linewidth=2)

// Coloring candles based on trade direction
BearCon = TradeisON and ShortTrade
BullCon = TradeisON and LongTrade

barcolor(BearCon ? RED : BullCon ? _Green : color.rgb(52, 52, 54))

plotcandle(open, high, low, close, 
     color = BearCon ? RED : BullCon ? _Green : color.rgb(52, 52, 54),
     wickcolor = color.rgb(103, 99, 99),
     bordercolor = BearCon ? RED : BullCon ? _Green : color.rgb(52, 52, 54))

bgcolor(BearCon ? color.new(color.red, 90) : BullCon ? color.new(color.green, 90) : na)

// Strategy performance table
var table perfTable = table.new(position.top_right, 2, 7, bgcolor=color.new(color.gray, 80))

updatePerformance() =>
    totalTrades = strategy.closedtrades
    winningTrades = strategy.wintrades
    losingTrades = strategy.losstrades
    grossProfit = strategy.grossprofit
    grossLoss = strategy.grossloss
    netPnL = strategy.netprofit

    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 0, "Winning Trades", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 0, str.tostring(winningTrades), text_color=color.green)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 1, "Losing Trades", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 1, str.tostring(losingTrades), text_color=color.red)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 2, "Gross Profit", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 2, str.tostring(grossProfit, format.mintick), text_color=color.green)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 3, "Gross Loss", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 3, str.tostring(grossLoss, format.mintick), text_color=color.red)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 4, "Net PnL", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 4, str.tostring(netPnL, format.mintick), text_color=netPnL >= 0 ? color.green : color.red)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 5, "Max Win Streak", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 5, str.tostring(maxWinStreak), text_color=color.green)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 6, "Max Loss Streak", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 6, str.tostring(maxLossStreak), text_color=color.red)

Example Prompt:

ith Your friends
Day 12 - A long (distance) day.  Got up around 7, packed and checked out.  My packing skills are getting better every time we move.  We had breakfast at the same cafe as yesterday, crossed the big boulevard to where the airport shuttle was parked yesterday.  But alas, the bus didn't come to that point.  It turned out that the bus stop was further up the street, and that it didn't leave on time.  We were supposed to be waiting for the 10:30, but it only started at 10:49.
I had succeeded in checking-in online for the first time (the last attempt in London failed and caused a bit of trouble at the counter).  I went to the baggage drop-off at Charles De Gaulles hoping to skip the line but ended up having to use the check in machine to print out my boarding pass and luggage tag and wait in line just the same. I don't really see any difference from the old way of checking in at the counter and leaving the luggage.  The only advantage was that we got to choose the seats beforehand, but it was only a 1 1/2 hour flight. Sorry, omit the first line: ith Your friends  Also make a list of the wordings you corrected so that I can tell what was the original expression and what is the corrected one.|||Translate to Thai: She broke out in a sweat at the thought. She couldn't think about this possibility now, she would get weak-kneed, panic and make some terrible mistake.

She still had the wire in her hand, but now she bent down and pushed it under the cupboard. It would be found there, but it didn't matter. When she was gone, she was gone, and they could know how she had managed it. She had pulled the wire out of a corsage after patiently undoing the seams with her fingernails. The girls didn't even have a nail file at their disposal, let alone a pair of scissors, and they even had to hand in hair clips when they got home. It was almost impossible to get hold of any kind of tool.

But Selina had managed it.

Because she was clever. But also, of course, because she had help.

Her cell phone was in her jeans pocket. The fact that she had managed to smuggle it past all the checks so far was nothing short of a miracle. It was certainly due to the fact that she had only been here for such a short time and there had been no room searches yet. As she had learned, they took place without any prior notice, and afterwards not a single item was left in its old place. Every crack in the wall, every niche, every cupboard compartment was turned upside down. But worst of all were the body searches, which Taisia carried out in person. Selina almost felt sick at the idea of this disgusting woman reaching into her every single orifice. Not to mention the fact that the cell phone would have been found by then at the latest, and she couldn't imagine what that would have entailed.|||Translate the following text from English into fluent, natural-sounding Mandarin, as a skilled human translator would. Make a table of monthly averages for the last 3 years.|||please review and optimise, if necessary, from a high-level investor point of view: Decarbonization and the Energy Transition in Germany
Germany's energy transition, known as the "Energiewende," is a comprehensive and ambitious plan to shift the country from fossil fuels and nuclear power to renewable energy sources. This transformation is driven by the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change.

Key Objectives of the Energiewende
Greenhouse Gas Reduction:

Germany aims to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 65% by 2030, compared to 1990 levels, and achieve climate neutrality by 2045â€‹ (EY US)â€‹.
Increase in Renewable Energy:

The target is for renewables to contribute at least 80% of the electricity supply by 2030. This involves significant investments in wind, solar, and other renewable energy sourcesâ€‹ (EY US)â€‹.
Phase-Out of Nuclear and Coal:

Germany plans to phase out nuclear power by the end of 2022 and coal by 2038, transitioning to a more sustainable energy mixâ€‹ (EY US)â€‹â€‹ (AI for Good)â€‹.
Decentralized Power Generation Model in Germany
Structure:

The new energy market model is characterized by decentralized power generation, utilizing a mix of renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and hydropower. Energy is produced closer to the point of consumption, often by individual households, businesses, and community projects.
Control:

A distributed control system where multiple small-scale producers and prosumers (consumers who also produce energy) participate.
The system relies on both supply-side and demand-side management, with a greater focus on real-time adjustments and energy efficiency.
Opportunities:

Lower Emissions: Increased use of renewable energy sources significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions.
Enhanced Resilience: Decentralized systems are more resilient to disruptions and can adapt more quickly to changes in demand and supply.
Local Benefits: Local generation keeps economic benefits within communities and creates jobs.
Technological Innovation: Adoption of smart grids, AI, and IoT technologies enhances the efficiency and reliability of energy systemsâ€‹ (EY US)â€‹â€‹ (AI for Good)â€‹â€‹ (EY US)â€‹.
Constraints of the New Model
Integration of Variable Renewables:

Challenge: Renewable energy sources such as wind and solar are variable and weather-dependent, making it challenging to balance supply and demand.
Solution: Advanced forecasting and real-time management technologies, including AI and machine learning, are crucial for optimizing the integration of these sourcesâ€‹ (AI for Good)â€‹.
Grid Management:

Challenge: Decentralized systems require sophisticated grid management to ensure stability and prevent outages.
Solution: Investment in smart grid technologies and decentralized energy storage solutions, such as Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), helps manage energy flows and maintain grid stabilityâ€‹ (McKinsey & Company)â€‹â€‹ (EY US)â€‹.
Regulatory and Market Adaptation:

Challenge: Existing regulatory frameworks and market structures are often designed for centralized systems and may not support the rapid deployment of decentralized generation.
Solution: Policymakers need to adapt regulations to facilitate distributed generation, grid access for small producers, and innovative market mechanisms such as dynamic pricing and demand response programsâ€‹ (CAF)â€‹â€‹ (EY US)â€‹.
The Need for Flexibility Development and Real-Time Optimization
As Germany transitions towards a decentralized and decarbonized energy model, the need for flexibility in managing energy resources and optimizing their use in real-time becomes critical.

Problem Analysis
Integration of Variable Renewables:

Challenge: Renewable energy sources such as wind and solar are variable and weather-dependent, making it challenging to balance supply and demand.
Impact: This variability can lead to periods of surplus energy production and times when energy supply is insufficient to meet demand, posing a threat to grid stabilityâ€‹ (AI for Good)â€‹.
Grid Management:

Challenge: Decentralized systems require sophisticated grid management to ensure stability and prevent outages.
Impact: Managing a decentralized grid with numerous small-scale energy producers and consumers is complex and requires advanced technology solutionsâ€‹ (McKinsey & Company)â€‹â€‹ (EY US)â€‹.
Regulatory and Market Adaptation:

Challenge: Existing regulatory frameworks and market structures are often designed for centralized systems and may not support the rapid deployment of decentralized generation.
Impact: Policymakers need to adapt regulations to facilitate distributed generation, grid access for small producers, and innovative market mechanisms such as dynamic pricing and demand response programsâ€‹ (CAF)â€‹â€‹ (EY US)â€‹.
Solution Analysis
Flexibility Development: The Role of Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS)

Flexibility:

Energy Storage: BESS store excess energy generated from renewable sources and release it during periods of high demand or low generation, providing crucial flexibility to the grid.
Grid Stability: BESS help manage the variability of renewables, reducing the need for fossil fuel backup and enhancing grid reliabilityâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹.
Co-Location with Renewables:

Efficiency: Co-locating BESS with wind and solar installations ensures more efficient use of generated power, reducing energy curtailment.
Stability: This integration supports the stability of the grid by allowing continuous energy supply even when renewable generation fluctuatesâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹.
Real-Time Optimization: The Use of AI and Advanced Technologies

Real-Time Management:

AI-Driven Optimization: AI and machine learning algorithms optimize BESS operations in real-time by adjusting charge and discharge cycles based on market conditions and grid requirements.
Forecasting: Advanced forecasting models predict energy prices, demand, and generation, allowing for better planning and utilization of BESSâ€‹ (AI for Good)â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹.
Algorithmic Trading:

Automated Trading: Self-learning algorithms execute trades autonomously, optimizing financial returns and reducing transaction costs.
Market Participation: AI enables strategic participation in energy markets, including frequency regulation and voltage support, enhancing revenue streamsâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹.
Summary
Germany's transition from a centralized to a decentralized power generation model requires the development of flexibility solutions such as Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) and real-time optimization technologies. These solutions address the inherent challenges of integrating variable renewable energy sources and maintaining grid stability. By leveraging advanced technologies like AI for real-time optimization and co-locating BESS with renewable sources, Germany can enhance resilience, reduce emissions, and create economic benefits. Strategic investments and regulatory adaptations are essential to fully realize these benefits and ensure a successful energy transition.|||Can you help us at getting to Tier I civilization? Then square C West relative to B. Then D North relative to C. Then E North relative to D. Then F East relative to E. Then G North relative to B. Then H West relative to D. Then I East relative to B. Then J East relative to G. Assuming I can only move between adjacent squares and assuming I am in H, and I want to get to J. What is the shortest path? Turbo the snail plays a game on a board with 2024 rows and 2023 columns. There are hidden monsters in 2022 of the cells. Initially, Turbo does not know where any of the monsters are, but he knows that there is exactly one monster in each row except the first row and the last row, and that each column contains at most one monster.

Turbo makes a series of attempts to go from the first row to the last row. On each attempt, he chooses to start on any cell in the first row, then repeatedly moves to an adjacent cell sharing a common side. (He is allowed to return to a previously visited cell.) If he reaches a cell with a monster, his attempt ends and he is transported back to the first row to start a new attempt. The monsters do not move, and Turbo remembers whether or not each cell he has visited contains a monster. If he reaches any cell in the last row, his attempt ends and the game is over.

Determine the minimum value of $n$ for which Turbo has a strategy that guarantees reaching the last row on the $n^{th}$ attempt or earlier, regardless of the locations of the monsters.

Let's analyze step by step. Description: The prompts discuss various aspects of vision health, including multifocal intraocular lenses, factors influencing myopia onset, the impact of eyewear on vision and perception, and considerations for hearing aids and light sensitivity.
Example Prompt:
do bullet points and include everything Multifocal IOLs (MFIOLs) achieve both distance and intermediate/near vision by divid- ing light into 2 or more focal points (Fig 9-4). This is achieved by either refractive or dif- fractive optics, or a combination of the 2. Several multifocal lenses (including toric MFIOLs) have been FDA-approved for use in the United States (Fig 9-5). Models are available in various power adds.
The advantage of MFIOLs is reduced dependence on spectacles. Disadvantages in- clude reduction in contrast sensitivity (which patients may perceive as dimmer vision), the presence of glare and halos (particularly in mesopic or scotopic conditions), and the presence of multiple images. Lower-add MFIOLs (ie, with their â€œnearâ€ focal point farther from the eye) may reduce some of these symptoms compared to higher-add MFIOLs. Patients with preoperative hyperopia may be less bothered by some of the visual aberrations associated with these lenses than patients with preoperative myopia. It is important for the cataract surgeon to counsel patients receiving MFIOLs about the intended postoperative visual outcome and limitations; a specialized consent process can be used.
MFIOLs are most suitable for use in patients with excellent ocular health; they can cause reduced quality of vision and unsatisfactory outcomes in patients with ocular pathology, such as amblyopia or diseases of the cornea, optic nerve (eg, glaucoma), or macula. MFIOLs work best when implanted bilaterally and when minimal postoperative astigmatism can be achieved. Options for patients unhappy with their uncorrected visual outcome due to residual postoperative refractive error include spectacle or contact lens correction, keratore- fractive surgery, or IOL exchange, preferably performed before capsular fibrosis increases the difficulty of explantation.

Description: The prompts focus on creating and converting various applications and scripts into Go, exploring project ideas to showcase Go skills, and understanding Go
Example Prompt:
convert the bash script below to a go program. the bash script is delimited by ```

```
export OUT_FIL=/tmp/merge-roster.json
rm -f "${OUT_FIL}"
touch "${OUT_FIL}"
echo $MERGE_ACCESS_KEY
echo $MERGE_TOKEN
CURSOR=""
while; do
    echo cursor ${CURSOR}

    RESP=$(curl -s -G 'https://api.merge.dev/api/hris/v1/employees' \
        -d 'page_size=100' \
        -d 'expand=employments,home_location,work_location,company' \
        -d "cursor=${CURSOR}" \
        -H "Authorization: Bearer ${MERGE_ACCESS_KEY}" \
        -H "X-Account-Token: ${MERGE_TOKEN}"
    )

    echo $RESP

    jq -r -c '.results[]' <<< "${RESP}" >> "${OUT_FIL}"


    CURSOR=$(jq -r '.next' <<< "${RESP}")
    if [[ "${CURSOR}" == "null" ]]; then
        break
    fi
done
```|||I am a front-end developer, and I code in React and C Sharp, Razor Pages, Blazor Pages. How would I incorporate Go into my applications?                 end_event_received = True

def get_access_token():
    """í† í° ë°œê¸‰"""
    headers = {"content-type":"application/json"}
    body = {"grant_type":"client_credentials",
    "appkey":APP_KEY, 
    "appsecret":APP_SECRET}
    PATH = "oauth2/tokenP"
    URL = f"{URL_BASE}/{PATH}"
    res = requests.post(URL, headers=headers, data=json.dumps(body))
    ACCESS_TOKEN = res.json()["access_token"]
    return ACCESS_TOKEN
    
def hashkey(datas):
    """ì•”í˜¸í™”"""
    PATH = "uapi/hashkey"
    URL = f"{URL_BASE}/{PATH}"
    headers = {
    'content-Type' : 'application/json',
    'appKey' : APP_KEY,
    'appSecret' : APP_SECRET,
    }
    res = requests.post(URL, headers=headers, data=json.dumps(datas))
    hashkey = res.json()["HASH"]
    return hashkey

from web3 import Web3

GAS_LIMIT = 300000

UNISWAP_ROUTER_ADDRESS = web3.to_checksum_address('0x7a250d5630b4cf539739df2c5dacf1f7e58634ba')

        ],
        "name": "swapExactETHForTokensSupportingFeeOnTransferTokens",
        "outputs": [{"name": "amounts", "type": "uint256[]"}],
        "payable": true,
        "stateMutability": "payable",
        "type": "function"
    }
]
""")

uniswap_router = web3.eth.contract(address=UNISWAP_ROUTER_ADDRESS, abi=UNISWAP_ROUTER_ABI)

# Function to send transaction
def send_transaction(transaction):
    signed_tx = web3.eth.account.sign_transaction(transaction, PRIVATE_KEY)
    tx_hash = web3.eth.send_raw_transaction(signed_tx.rawTransaction)
    print(f'Transaction sent: {tx_hash.hex()}')
    return tx_hash

# Function to estimate profitability
def is_profitable(target_tx):
    try:
        target_data = web3.eth.get_transaction(target_tx)
        input_data = target_data['input']

        # Assuming input_data can be decoded to get amountIn and path
        # For simplicity, let's assume you get the amountIn and path
        # You'll need to decode input_data properly in a real scenario
        amount_in = 1 * 10**18  # Example value, replace with actual
        path = [web3.to_checksum_address('0xC02aaA39b223FE8D0A0e5C4F27eAD9083C756Cc2'),  # WETH
                web3.to_checksum_address('0x2260FAC5E5542a773Aa44fBCfeDf7C193bc2C599')]  # WBTC

        # Fetch output amounts
        amounts_out = uniswap_router.functions.getAmountsOut(amount_in, path).call()
        potential_profit = amounts_out[-1] - amount_in  # Simplified

        # Calculate gas cost
        gas_cost = GAS_PRICE * GAS_LIMIT

        return potential_profit > gas_cost
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Error estimating profitability: {e}")
        return False

# Function to create sandwich attack
def sandwich_attack(target_tx):
    if is_profitable(target_tx):
        try:
            # Decode the target transaction data
            target_data = web3.eth.get_transaction(target_tx)
            input_data = target_data['input']

            # Front-running transaction
            front_tx = {
                'from': WALLET_ADDRESS,
                'to': UNISWAP_ROUTER_ADDRESS,
                'value': web3.to_wei('1', 'ether'),
                'gas': GAS_LIMIT,
                'gasPrice': GAS_PRICE,
                'nonce': web3.eth.get_transaction_count(WALLET_ADDRESS),
                'data': input_data
            }
            send_transaction(front_tx)

            # Wait for the target transaction to be mined
            time.sleep(5)

            # Back-running transaction
            back_tx = {
                'from': WALLET_ADDRESS,
                'to': UNISWAP_ROUTER_ADDRESS,
                'value': 0,
                'gas': GAS_LIMIT,
                'gasPrice': GAS_PRICE,
                'nonce': web3.eth.get_transaction_count(WALLET_ADDRESS) + 1,
                'data': input_data
            }
            send_transaction(back_tx)
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error processing transaction {target_tx}: {e}")

# Monitor mempool for target transactions
def monitor_mempool():
    print("Monitoring mempool for transactions...")
    pending_filter = web3.eth.filter('pending')
    while True:
        pending_txs = pending_filter.get_new_entries()
        print(f"Found {len(pending_txs)} pending transactions.")
        for tx_hash in pending_txs:
            retry_count = 0
            max_retries = 5
            while retry_count < max_retries:
                try:
                    print(f"Trying to get transaction {tx_hash.hex()} (attempt {retry_count + 1}/{max_retries})")
                    tx = web3.eth.get_transaction(tx_hash)
                    if tx:
                        print(f"Transaction to: {tx['to']}")
                        print(f"Transaction input: {tx['input'][:10]}...")  # Print first 10 characters of input data
                    if tx and tx['to'] == UNISWAP_ROUTER_ADDRESS:
                        # Check if WETH is part of the transaction path
                        if WETH_ADDRESS in tx['input']:
                            print(f"Processing transaction {tx_hash.hex()} involving ETH pair...")
                            sandwich_attack(tx_hash)
                            break
                        else:
                            print(f"Transaction {tx_hash.hex()} does not involve WETH, skipping...")
                            break
                    else:
                        print(f"Transaction {tx_hash.hex()} not matching criteria, skipping...")
                        break
                except TransactionNotFound:
                    print(f"Transaction {tx_hash.hex()} not found, retrying ({retry_count+1}/{max_retries})...")
                    retry_count += 1
                    time.sleep(3)  # Increased delay
                except Exception as e:
                    print(f"An error occurred: {e}")
                    break

if __name__ == '__main__':
    monitor_mempool()|||nasdaq_trader_plus/

        blog_service: BlogPostServices = Depends(BlogPostServices)
    ):
